# Source: https://biomejs.dev/guides/getting-started/

# Getting Started 

Biome is best installed as a development dependency of your projects, but it is also available as a [standalone executable](/guides/manual-installation) that doesn't require Node.js.

-   [![](data:image/svg+xml;base64,) npm](#tab-panel-167)
-   [![](data:image/svg+xml;base64,) pnpm](#tab-panel-168)
-   [![](data:image/svg+xml;base64,) bun](#tab-panel-169)
-   [![](data:image/svg+xml;base64,) deno](#tab-panel-170)
-   [![](data:image/svg+xml;base64,) yarn](#tab-panel-171)

<figure class="frame not-content">
<pre data-language="bash"><code>1npm i -D -E @biomejs/biome</code></pre>
<div class="copy">
<div>

</div>
</div>
</figure>

<figure class="frame not-content">
<pre data-language="bash"><code>1pnpm add -D -E @biomejs/biome</code></pre>
<div class="copy">
<div>

</div>
</div>
</figure>

<figure class="frame not-content">
<pre data-language="bash"><code>1bun add -D -E @biomejs/biome</code></pre>
<div class="copy">
<div>

</div>
</div>
</figure>

<figure class="frame not-content">
<pre data-language="bash"><code>1deno add -D npm:@biomejs/biome</code></pre>
<div class="copy">
<div>

</div>
</div>
</figure>

<figure class="frame not-content">
<pre data-language="bash"><code>1yarn add -D -E @biomejs/biome</code></pre>
<div class="copy">
<div>

</div>
</div>
</figure>

![](data:image/svg+xml;base64,)Version pinning

`-E` ensures that the package manager pins the version of Biome. See the [versioning page](/internals/versioning) for more information about [why pinning the version is important](/internals/versioning#why-pinning-the-version-is-important).

## Configuration

[[![](data:image/svg+xml;base64,)][Section titled "Configuration"]](#configuration)

Although Biome can run with zero configuration, you'll likely want to tweak some settings to suit your project's needs, in which case you can run the following command to generate a `biome.json` configuration file.

-   [![](data:image/svg+xml;base64,) npm](#tab-panel-172)
-   [![](data:image/svg+xml;base64,) pnpm](#tab-panel-173)
-   [![](data:image/svg+xml;base64,) bun](#tab-panel-174)
-   [![](data:image/svg+xml;base64,) deno](#tab-panel-175)
-   [![](data:image/svg+xml;base64,) yarn](#tab-panel-176)

<figure class="frame not-content">
<pre data-language="bash"><code>1npx @biomejs/biome init</code></pre>
<div class="copy">
<div>

</div>
</div>
</figure>

<figure class="frame not-content">
<pre data-language="bash"><code>1pnpm exec biome init</code></pre>
<div class="copy">
<div>

</div>
</div>
</figure>

<figure class="frame not-content">
<pre data-language="bash"><code>1bunx --bun biome init</code></pre>
<div class="copy">
<div>

</div>
</div>
</figure>

<figure class="frame not-content">
<pre data-language="bash"><code>1deno run -A npm:@biomejs/biome init</code></pre>
<div class="copy">
<div>

</div>
</div>
</figure>

<figure class="frame not-content">
<pre data-language="bash"><code>1yarn exec biome init</code></pre>
<div class="copy">
<div>

</div>
</div>
</figure>

## Usage

[[![](data:image/svg+xml;base64,)][Section titled "Usage"]](#usage)

Lets get a quick overview of how to use Biome in your project.

### Command-line interface

[[![](data:image/svg+xml;base64,)][Section titled "Command-line interface"]](#command-line-interface)

Biome provides a [command-line interface](/reference/cli) to format, lint, and check your code.

-   [![](data:image/svg+xml;base64,) npm](#tab-panel-177)
-   [![](data:image/svg+xml;base64,) pnpm](#tab-panel-178)
-   [![](data:image/svg+xml;base64,) bun](#tab-panel-179)
-   [![](data:image/svg+xml;base64,) deno](#tab-panel-180)
-   [![](data:image/svg+xml;base64,) yarn](#tab-panel-181)

<figure class="frame not-content">
<pre data-language="bash"><code>1# Format all files2npx @biomejs/biome format --write3
4# Format specific files5npx @biomejs/biome format --write &lt;files&gt;6
7# Lint files and apply safe fixes to all files8npx @biomejs/biome lint --write9
10# Lint files and apply safe fixes to specific files11npx @biomejs/biome lint --write &lt;files&gt;12
13# Format, lint, and organize imports of all files14npx @biomejs/biome check --write15
16# Format, lint, and organize imports of specific files17npx @biomejs/biome check --write &lt;files&gt;</code></pre>
<div class="copy">
<div>

</div>
</div>
</figure>

<figure class="frame not-content">
<pre data-language="bash"><code>1# Format all files2pnpm exec biome format --write3
4# Format specific files5pnpm exec biome format --write &lt;files&gt;6
7# Lint and apply safe fixes to all files8pnpm exec biome lint --write9
10# Lint files and apply safe fixes to specific files11pnpm exec biome lint --write &lt;files&gt;12
13# Format, lint, and organize imports of all files14pnpm exec biome check --write15
16# Format, lint, and organize imports of specific files17pnpm exec biome check --write &lt;files&gt;</code></pre>
<div class="copy">
<div>

</div>
</div>
</figure>

<figure class="frame not-content">
<pre data-language="bash"><code>1# Format all files2bunx biome format --write3
4# Format specific files5bunx biome format --write &lt;files&gt;6
7# Lint and apply safe fixes to all files8bunx biome lint --write9
10# Lint files and apply safe fixes to specific files11bunx biome lint --write &lt;files&gt;12
13# Format, lint, and organize imports of all files14bunx biome check --write15
16# Format, lint, and organize imports of specific files17bunx biome check --write &lt;files&gt;</code></pre>
<div class="copy">
<div>

</div>
</div>
</figure>

<figure class="frame not-content">
<pre data-language="bash"><code>1# Format specific files2deno run -A npm:@biomejs/biome format --write &lt;files&gt;3
4# Format all files5deno run -A npm:@biomejs/biome format --write6
7# Lint files and apply safe fixes to all files8deno run -A npm:@biomejs/biome lint --write9
10# Lint files and apply safe fixes to specific files11deno run -A npm:@biomejs/biome lint --write &lt;files&gt;12
13# Format, lint, and organize imports of all files14deno run -A npm:@biomejs/biome check --write15
16# Format, lint, and organize imports of specific files17deno run -A npm:@biomejs/biome check --write &lt;files&gt;</code></pre>
<div class="copy">
<div>

</div>
</div>
</figure>

<figure class="frame not-content">
<pre data-language="bash"><code>1# Format all files2yarn exec biome format --write3
4# Format specific files5yarn exec biome format --write &lt;files&gt;6
7# Lint files and apply safe fixes to all files8yarn exec biome lint --write9
10# Lint files and apply safe fixes to specific files11yarn exec biome lint --write &lt;files&gt;12
13# Format, lint, and organize imports of all files14yarn exec biome check --write15
16# Format, lint, and organize imports of specific files17yarn exec biome check --write &lt;files&gt;</code></pre>
<div class="copy">
<div>

</div>
</div>
</figure>

### Editor integrations

[[![](data:image/svg+xml;base64,)][Section titled "Editor integrations"]](#editor-integrations)

Biome is available as a first-party extension in your favorite editors.

-   [VS Code](/guides/editors/first-party-extensions#vs-code)
-   [IntelliJ](/guides/editors/first-party-extensions#intellij)
-   [Zed](/guides/editors/first-party-extensions#zed)

There are also [community extensions](/guides/editors/third-party-extensions) for other editors, such as **Vim**, **Neovim**, and **Sublime Text**, to name a few.

### Continuous Integration

[[![](data:image/svg+xml;base64,)][Section titled "Continuous Integration"]](#continuous-integration)

Run `biome ci` as part of your CI pipeline to enforce code quality and consistency across your team. It works just like the `biome check` command, but is optimized for CI environments.

-   [GitHub Actions](/recipes/continuous-integration#github-actions)
-   [GitLab CI](/recipes/continuous-integration#gitlab-ci)

See the [Continuous Integration](/recipes/continuous-integration) recipes for more examples.

## Next Steps

[[![](data:image/svg+xml;base64,)][Section titled "Next Steps"]](#next-steps)

Success! You're now ready to use Biome. ðŸ¥³

-   Learn more about how to use and configure the [linter](/linter)
-   Get familiar with the [CLI commands and options](/reference/cli)
-   Get familiar with the [configuration options](/reference/configuration)
